title: A view from the street as Hong Kong descends further into violence
text:
AFR Correspondent Michael Smith finds a dark and violent mood on the streets of what was once a vibrant Asian financial centre.

Hong Kong | Hong Kong's Nathan Road, a popular shopping street familiar to many Australians, was a war zone by nightfall on Sunday.

Metro station entrances and a Chinese electronics shop were on fire, shops and ATM machines were trashed, and the roads were littered with bricks, broken glass and metal poles. Police fired a water cannon with blue dye which splashed onto the steps of the city's most prominent mosque, injuring bystanders and some journalists.

At one point local residents ran screaming down side streets as police fired rounds of tear gas into a crowd of people who were clearly not protesters. Parents with young children ran for cover, an elderly woman was seen throwing up as first aid volunteers rushed to her aid.

Diners stared from the windows of restaurants and hotels, alarmed at the scenes outside. Everywhere, people were coughing and covering their faces.

These are now familiar scenes as the Hong Kong protests enter their 20th consecutive weekend. But the mood is angrier, the violence more senseless than ever, and there is no end in sight to the five-month long political crisis.

Walking down Nathan Road later that evening towards the Star Ferry, I witnessed a trail of destruction. MTR entrances, traffic lights, bank branches and a chain of snack food stores were trashed. Anti-police and government graffiti was spray-painted on every available surface and most of the shops were closed.
description: AFR Correspondent Michael Smith finds a dark and violent mood on the streets of what was once a vibrant Asian financial centre.
